Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative: New GK12: Building Ocean Literacy in a Coastal Community through Science Education and Estuarine Monitoring

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Savannah State University (SSU), the Skidaway Institute of Oceanography, and the Savannah Chatham Public School System (SCPSS) will engage graduate students, scientists, and K-12 teachers and students in a sustainable research-based education program to promote ocean literacy, science education, and research in coastal Georgia. The goal of the ?Building Ocean Literacy Program? is to expand ocean literacy and cultivate research skills in K-12 classrooms while developing graduate student skills in communicating science concepts to people beyond the research community. The program will pair marine science GK-12 fellows from a historically black university (SSU) with master science teachers and classes within the SCPSS. African-American students are over-represented in the SCPSS compared to the national average and the program will reach a wide and diverse audience. Fellows will engage classes in estuarine monitoring and in their graduate research activities to enhance research skills and ocean literacy in the school system. New graduate coursework will develop communication and teaching skills among GK-12 fellows, while teacher training opportunities will enhance teacher awareness of marine issues. Research activities of GK-12 fellows, teachers, and public school students, will focus on the local estuarine ecosystem and will directly support Georgia Performance Standards. Research and instructional components of this project will collectively 1) promote ocean literacy in K-12 classrooms, 2) enhance K-12 science instruction in Chatham County public schools, and 3) train the next generation of scientists to be competent, comfortable, and engaged in communicating science concepts to a wide array of audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Graduate STEM Fellows in K-12 Education (GK-12) Program supported fellowships and training for graduate students in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).  The goal of the program was to provide opportunities for graduate students to improve their communication skills by fostering interactions with teachers and students in K-12 schools and to enrich STEM content and instruction in K-12 schools.

 From 2009 through 2015 in partnership with the Savannah Chatham County Public School System (SCPSS) in Savannah Georgia, the University of Georgia Skidaway Institute of Oceanography (SkIO) collaborated with Savannah State University (SSU) to host the GK 12 program  “Ocean Literacy in a Coastal Community through Science Education and Estuarine Monitoring”.  SkIO is an internationally respected oceanographic research institute, SSU is a historically black university that offers graduate degrees (MS) in Marine Sciences, and African-American students are over-represented in the SCPSS compared to the national average.  The goals of this project were to 1) build Ocean Literacy and sustainable partnerships at SSU that would enhance both education and research in the Southeast USA and 2) to increase the engagement of underrepresented students in the ocean sciences. 

The components of the program included 1) engaging SSU graduate students in coastal relevant research, 2) pairing graduate students with K-12 educators to assist in teaching and infuse K-12 classrooms with Ocean Literacy content. The presence of graduate students in these classrooms allowed more hands on and lab activities to be conducted than would have otherwise been possible.  A third component of the project was to offer opportunities for educators to increase their Ocean Literacy by offering content-rich workshops, internships, research cruise experiences, field work, and mentorship experiences.   

During the project 25 marine science graduate students served as “resident scientists” in local science classrooms ranging from elementary through high school. As reported by the students who completed these residences, these experiences were a transformative component of their graduate experience that improved their communication and teaching skills. Also as a result of this program a strong partnership was developed with Savannah-Chatham public schools that we expect to continue well beyond the completion of this project. Reciprocally, K-12 educators who participated in the program report increasing their Ocean Literacy and their appreciation of the research process. Many of the educators report that they regularly include information and the insights gained in their classrooms. 

The impact of the SSU/SkIO GK 12 program is likely to be sustained.  As of March 2016, 14 of the fellows have graduated, while 11 are actively completing their degree requirements.  44% of the GK-12 graduate fellows have been from groups underrepresented in the geosciences and they served a school system that is 57% African American and 67% economically disadvantaged. Pre-tests and post-test results showed improvement in basic Ocean Literacy in local classrooms and in educators that participated in the workshops. The classroom immersion and effective mentor-mentee relationships resulted in a large fraction of the former fellows (50%) going on to careers in science education including higher education, high schools and public aquaria. Others are employed with governmental agencies, in research labs, or at environmental firms. Three of the graduates are now enrolled in PhD Programs. Through refinement of instructional strategies, by the last year of the project, 100% of active fellows submitted science education articles for publication.
